timeline.body: I think `assertEquals()` expects expected item as the first argument and actual arguments as the second. You need to swap these
timeline.bodyText: I think assertEquals() expects expected item as the first argument and actual arguments as the second. You need to swap these
timeline.bodyHTML: I think assertEquals() expects expected item as the first argument and actual arguments as the second. You need to swap these

timeline.bodyHTML:
Please, remove the comments:

Suggested change
//Given
// Both version are null
//When
//Then
assertNull(EnvUtil.extractLargerVersion(null,null));
assertNull(EnvUtil.extractLargerVersion(null,null));

Or replace by declarative code:

Suggested change
//Given
// Both version are null
//When
//Then
assertNull(EnvUtil.extractLargerVersion(null,null));
//Given
var v1 = null;
var v2 = null;
//When
var result = EnvUtil.extractLargerVersion(v1, v2);
//Then
assertNull(result);
timeline.author: manusa

timeline.body: This is very bad, try not to use this in tests ever. I don't even see the purpose of this sleep/wait in the test.

replies.bodyText: I suggested him to use Thread.sleep() since the test is measuring time duration since a specified value
replies.author: rohanKanojia

replies.bodyText:
Never use Thread.sleep in tests!
For this test, I don't even understand why we are using system.currentTimeMillis();, but if this is really necessary, then you can simply replace by:

  
    
  
    

  
  This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                    Thread.sleep(200L);
          
          
            
            long startTime = System.currentTimeMillis() - 200L;
          
      
    
    
  

Some quick Googled sources with reasons why you shouldn't (although there are maaaany bad reasons to do so)

http://www.kyleblaney.com/junit-best-practices#:~:text=Do%20not%20use%20Thread.&text=When%20a%20unit%20test%20uses,the%20production%20code%20is%20broken.
https://laurentkempe.com/2012/11/20/Using-ThreadSleep-in-unit-test-A-good-idea/
replies.author: manusa

timeline.body: Platform dependent test. Try to make it platform independent and provide two tests, one that verifies it is windows and one that verifies it's not.
